tit.j: 若宮八幡宮 (京都市東山区)
tit.e: Wakamiya Hachiman-gu Shrine (Higashiyama Ward, Kyoto City)

sen.j: 若宮八幡宮（わかみやはちまんぐう）は、京都市東山区に鎮座する神社。
sen.e: Wakamiya Hachiman-gu Shrine is a Shinto shrine located in Higashiyama Ward, Kyoto City.
Wakamiya Hachiman-gu Shrine is a Shinto shrine located in Higashiyama Ward, Kyoto City.
Wakamiya Hachiman-gu Shrine is a Shinto shrine located in Higashiyama Ward, Kyoto City.

sen.j: 陶器神社とも呼ばれる。
sen.e: It is also referred to by the name "Toki-jinja" (lit. Pottery Shrine).
It is also referred to by the name "Toki-jinja" (lit. Pottery Shrine).
It is also referred to by the name "Toki-jinja" (lit. Pottery Shrine).

sen.j: 旧社格は郷社。
sen.e: It was classified as a gosha under the old shrine ranking system.
It was classified as a gosha under the old shrine ranking system.
It was classified as a gosha (village shrine) under the old shrine ranking system.

sen.j: 応神天皇・仲哀天皇・神功皇后（八幡神）を主祭神とし、左相殿に仲恭天皇、右相殿に椎根津彦大神（陶祖神）を配祀する。
sen.e: The main enshrined deities are Emperor Ojin, Emperor Chuai and Empress Jingu (Hachiman-shin) which are accompanied by Emperor Chukyo who is enshrined in the left-aidono and Shiinetsuhiko no okami (the god for the pottery) in the right-aidono.

The main enshrined deities are Emperor Ojin, Emperor Chuai and Empress Jingu (Hachiman-shin) which are accompanied by Emperor Chukyo who is enshrined in the left-aidono and Shiinetsuhiko no okami (the god for the pottery) in the right-aidono.

The main enshrined deities are the Emperor Ojin, the Emperor Chuai and the Empress Jingu (Hachiman-shin) which are accompanied by the Emperor Chukyo who is enshrined in the left-aidono and Shiinetsuhiko no okami (the god for the pottery) in the right-aidono.

sen.j: 由緒
sen.e: History
History
History

sen.j: 天喜元年（1053年）、仏説による末法思想の世の1年目にあたることから、後冷泉天皇の勅願により源頼義が六条左女牛井(さめがい)の地に造営し、創建された。
sen.e: Wakamiya Hachiman-gu Shrine was founded 1054 in Rokujo Samegai by Yoriyoshi MINAMOTO under the imperial order of Emperor Go-Reizai due to the first year of the Age of Dharma Decline according to Buddha's teachings.

Wakamiya Hachiman-gu Shrine was founded 1054 in Rokujo Samegai by Yoriyoshi MINAMOTO under the imperial order of Emperor Go-Reizai due to the first year of the Age of Dharma Decline according to Buddha's teachings.

Wakamiya Hachiman-gu Shrine was founded 1053 in Rokujo Samegai by Yoriyoshi MINAMOTO under the imperial order of the Emperor Goreizei due to the first year of the Age of Dharma Decline according to Buddha's teachings.
sen.cmt: 数字修正天皇表記"the" を追加しました。

sen.j: 当時は左女牛八幡宮、六条八幡宮とも称した。
sen.e: At this time, it was also known as Samegai Hachiman-gu Shrine and Rokujo Hachiman-gu Shrine.
At this time, it was also known as Samegai Hachiman-gu Shrine and Rokujo Hachiman-gu Shrine.
At this time, it was also known as Samegai Hachiman-gu Shrine and Rokujo Hachiman-gu Shrine.

sen.j: その後前九年の役で源頼義、源義家親子が大功をたてたことから源氏に厚く崇敬され、鎌倉親王家ならびに将軍家代々の社参が恒例となる。
sen.e: The shrine later became deeply revered by the Minamoto clan following the success of Yoriyoshi MINAMOTO and his son Yoshiie MINAMOTO during the Zenkunen War, and it became customary for Kamakura Imperial Princes and successive shogun families to visit.

The shrine later became deeply revered by the Minamoto clan following the success of Yoriyoshi MINAMOTO and his son Yoshiie MINAMOTO during the Zenkunen War, and it became customary for Kamakura Imperial Princes and successive shogun families to visit.

The shrine later became deeply revered by the Minamoto clan following the success of Yoriyoshi MINAMOTO and his son Yoshiie MINAMOTO during the Zenkunen War, and it became customary for Kamakura Imperial Princes and successive shogun families to visit.

sen.j: 建久元年(1190年)と同6年の源頼朝上洛社参時には臨時の大祭を斎行し、諸国に神領を寄せ神宝を奉納した。
sen.e: Special grand festivals were held during visits made to the shrine by Yoritomo MINAMOTO in 1190 and 1195 who granted the shrine estates in numerous provinces and made offerings of sacred treasures.
Special grand festivals were held during visits made to the shrine by Yoritomo MINAMOTO in 1190 and 1195 who granted the shrine estates in numerous provinces and made offerings of sacred treasures.
Special grand festivals were held during visits made to the shrine by Yoritomo MINAMOTO in 1190 and 1195 who granted the shrine estates in numerous provinces and made offerings of sacred treasures.

sen.j: 源義経は頼義・義家に倣い、社地の近くに館を構えた。
sen.e: MINAMOTO no Yoshitsune imitated Yoriyoshi and Yoshiie in building a residence near to the shrine.
MINAMOTO no Yoshitsune imitated Yoriyoshi and Yoshiie in building a residence near to the shrine.
MINAMOTO no Yoshitsune imitated Yoriyoshi and Yoshiie in building a residence near to the shrine.

sen.j: 足利将軍家も代々社参し、足利尊氏は七種の神宝、足利尊氏は社領知行安堵状、足利義政は五拾壱ヶ所の地所を奉納した。
sen.e: Successive generations of the Ashikaga shogun family also visited the shrine, with Takauji ASHIKAGA offering seven kinds of sacred treasures and a letter officially recognizing the shrine's fiefdom, and Yoshimasa ASHIKAGA dedicating to the shrine 31 areas of land.

Successive generations of the Ashikaga shogun family also visited the shrine, with Takauji ASHIKAGA offering seven kinds of sacred treasures and a letter officially recognizing the shrine's fiefdom, and Yoshimasa ASHIKAGA dedicating to the shrine 31 areas of land.

Successive generations of the Ashikaga Shogun family also visited the shrine, with Takauji ASHIKAGA offering seven kinds of sacred treasures and a letter officially recognizing the shrine's fiefdom, and Yoshimasa ASHIKAGA dedicating to the shrine 51 areas of land.
sen.cmt: 数字修正"shogun" -> "Shogun" に変更しました。

sen.j: 応仁の乱では社殿が炎上したが、足利義輝及び足利義昭発起により諸国の武家に寄附を募り、再建された。
sen.e: The shrine buildings were damaged by fire during the Onin War but were rebuilt using donations solicited from the warrior households of numerous provinces at the request of Yoshiteru ASHIKAGA and Yoshiaki ASHIKAGA.

The shrine buildings were damaged by fire during the Onin War but were rebuilt using donations solicited from the warrior households of numerous provinces at the request of Yoshiteru ASHIKAGA and Yoshiaki ASHIKAGA.

The shrine buildings were damaged by fire during the Onin War but were rebuilt using donations solicited from the warrior households of numerous provinces at the request of Yoshiteru ASHIKAGA and Yoshiaki ASHIKAGA.

sen.j: ほか織田信長、大内義隆、毛利氏三家、細川氏、三好氏、朝倉氏などより神地、神馬、太刀等を奉納される。
sen.e: In addition, sacred land, sacred horses and tachi swords were donated by, among others, Nobunaga ODA, Yoshitaka OUCHI, the three houses of the Mori clan, the Hosokawa clan, the Miyoshi clan and the Asakura clan,

In addition, sacred land, sacred horses and tachi swords were donated by, among others, Nobunaga ODA, Yoshitaka OUCHI, the three houses of the Mori clan, the Hosokawa clan, the Miyoshi clan and the Asakura clan,

In addition, sacred land, sacred horses and tachi swords were donated by, among others, Nobunaga ODA, Yoshitaka OUCHI, the three houses of the Mori clan, the Hosokawa clan, the Miyoshi clan and the Asakura clan,

sen.j: 天正11年（1583年）、豊臣秀吉による京都改造により御旅所のあった東山に移り、16年には方広寺の北に移る。
sen.e: As a result of the reconstruction of Kyoto by Hideyoshi TOYOTOMI, Wakamiya Hachiman-gu Shrine was relocated to the place where the sacred palanquin was lodged during festivals in Higashiyama in 1583, and moved again to the north of Hoko-ji Temple in 1588.

As a result of the reconstruction of Kyoto by Hideyoshi TOYOTOMI, Wakamiya Hachiman-gu Shrine was relocated to the place where the sacred palanquin was lodged during festivals in Higashiyama in 1583, and moved again to the north of Hoko-ji Temple in 1588.

As a result of the reconstruction of Kyoto by Hideyoshi TOYOTOMI, Wakamiya Hachiman-gu Shrine was relocated to the place where the sacred palanquin was lodged during festivals in Higashiyama in 1583, and moved again to the north of Hoko-ji Temple in 1588.

sen.j: 秀吉の死後、慶長10年（1605年）に現社地に鎮座。
sen.e: After Hideyoshi's death, the shrine was relocated to its current site.
After Hideyoshi's death, the shrine was relocated to its current site.
After Hideyoshi's death in 1605, the shrine was relocated to its current site.

sen.j: 元和 (日本)元年（1615年）、徳川家康より神領七十三石八斗余を寄進される。
sen.e: In 1615, Ieyasu TOKUGAWA granted the shrine an estate with a value of over 73-koku, 8-masu (approximately 11,000kg of rice).
In 1615, Ieyasu TOKUGAWA granted the shrine an estate with a value of over 73-koku, 8-masu (approximately 11,000kg of rice).
In 1615, Ieyasu TOKUGAWA granted the shrine an estate with a value of over 73-koku, 8-masu (approximately 11,000 kg of rice).

sen.j: 承応3年(1654年)、後光明天皇が父後水尾上皇の考えにより社殿を造営。
sen.e: A new shrine building was constructed in 1654 at the will of Retired Emperor Go-mizunoo, son of Emperor Go-Komyo.
A new shrine building was constructed in 1654 at the will of Retired Emperor Go-mizunoo, son of Emperor Go-Komyo.
A new shrine building was constructed in 1654 at the will of Retired Emperor Gomizunoo, son of the Emperor Gokomyo.
sen.cmt: 天皇表記"the" を追加しました。

sen.j: 現在の本殿にあたる。
sen.e: This is the current main sanctuary.
This is the current main sanctuary.
This is the current main sanctuary.

sen.j: 明治10年（1877年）、宮内省によって本町十六丁目の塚本社から仲恭天皇の神霊が奉還される。
sen.e: In 1877, the Department of the Imperial Household transferred the divine spirit of Emperor Chukyo from Tsukamoto-sha Shrine in Honmachi juroku chome and enshrined at Wakamiya Hachiman-gu Shrine.
In 1877, the Department of the Imperial Household transferred the divine spirit of Emperor Chukyo from Tsukamoto-sha Shrine in Honmachi juroku chome and enshrined at Wakamiya Hachiman-gu Shrine.
In 1877, the Department of the Imperial Household transferred the divine spirit of the Emperor Chukyo from Tsukamoto-sha Shrine in Honmachi juroku chome and enshrined at Wakamiya Hachiman-gu Shrine.

sen.j: 同24年、陶祖神椎根津彦命を合祀。
sen.e: The pottery god Shiinetsuhiko no okami was enshrined in 1891.
The pottery god Shiinetsuhiko no okami was enshrined in 1891.
The pottery god Shiinetsuhiko no okami was enshrined in 1891.

sen.e: 1st January: Gantan-sai (New Year's Day Festival)

sen.e: 3rd January: Prayer festival for the prosperity of family fortunes and business

sen.j: 1月7日：七種粥神事
sen.e: 7th January: Nanakusa-gayu Shinji (rice porridge with seven herbs eaten on the 7th day of the New Year)
7th January: Nanakusa-gayu Shinji (rice porridge with seven herbs eaten on the 7th day of the New Year)
January 7: Nanakusa-gayu Shinji (rice porridge with seven herbs eaten on the 7th day of the New Year)

sen.e: 15th January: Seijin-sai (Adult Festival); Shinnen-sai (New Year Festival)
15th January: Seijin-sai (Adult Festival); Shinnen-sai (New Year Festival)
January 15: Seijin-sai (Adult Festival); Shinnen-sai (New Year Festival)

sen.j: 2月3日（又は4日）：節分祭（本社）、初午祭（末社稲荷社）
sen.e: 3rd (or 4th) February: Setsubun-sai (festival for the last day of winter) (held at the main temple); Hatsuuma-sai (First Horse Day festival) (held at the Inari-sha subsidiary shrine)

sen.j: 4月29日：天長節祭
